frameDefinitions: The words in this frame have to do with non-verbal communication.
This frame contains nouns that refer to sensations in different modalities.
In this frame either a Stimulus brings about a particular emotion or experience in the Experiencer or  saliently fails to bring about a particular experience.
A Topic or Stimulus fails or succeeds at causing an emotion in an Experiencer, which is conveyed by an Expressor or manifested in a State or description of an Event.
A Communicator conveys a Message to an Addressee; the Topic and Medium of the communication also may be expressed.
A phenomenon, the Indicator, exists as an indication of another phenomenon, the Indicated.
frameExamples: I <t>gestured</t> with my hand for him to come over.
The huge sand dunes, perpetually changing, make for a surreal <t>sight</t>.
Let's hope it did n't have time to <t>communicate</t> any of its findings to its overlords.
This is a <t>sign</t> of things to come.
listRoleDefinitions: This is the sentient entity that communicates a Message non-verbally. It is normally expressed as an External Argument: <fex name='Communicator'>The teacher</fex> <t>gestured</t> us into the room.

This is the person to whom a non-verbal Message is communicated. It may be expressed as an NP Object or as a PP Complement: The teacher <t>gestured</t> <fex name='Addressee'>us</fex> into the room. The teacher <t>gestured</t> <fex name='Addressee'>to us</fex> to enter the room.

This is the content of non-verbal communication. It may be expressed as a <ment>that</ment>-clause Complement, a <ment>to</ment>-marked infinitive VP Complement, or a directional PP Complement: The teacher <t>gestured</t> <fex name='Message'>that it was time to leave</fex>. The teacher <t>gestured</t> to us <fex name='Message'>to enter the room</fex>. The teacher <t>gestured</t> us <fex name='Message'>into the room</fex>.
The <fen>Body_part</fen> is the specific body part of the <fen>Communicator</fen> which gestures.
The <fen>Indicated_entity</fen> is the entity which the <fen>Communicator</fen> is pointing out to the <fen>Addressee</fen> as meaningful.
When the gesturing occus.
The <fen>Place</fen> is where the gesturing occurs.
This role is only expressed with certain nouns in this frame, and then only with the help of a support verb, such as <ment>have</ment>:

This is the entity or phenomenon which gives rise to the sensation. In cases of veridical sensation, this role is not typically distinguished from <fen>Percept</fen>. Most of the phrases that express this role can be paraphrased as <ment>from</ment>-phrases, e.g.

The role <fen>Percept</fen> is used for phrases that express the characteristic property of a sensation. Typically this characteristic property is described with reference to the entity or phenomenon that produces the sensation---that  is why this role can be difficult to distinguish from Source. It is possible for Source and Percept to be expressed separately, however:

This role is assigned to phrases expressing the body part in which a sensation is located. Since touch is the least localized of sense modalities, words relating to haptic sensations are the ones most likely to occur with this FE:
This role is the perceptual background against which the Phenomenon is experienced by the Perceiver.
The <fen>Time</fen> when the sensation is perceived.
The <fen>Stimulus</fen> is the object or event which brings about the emotion in the <fen>Experiencer</fen>.
The <fen>Experiencer</fen> is the person or sentient entity that experiences or feels the emotions.
The <fen>Topic</fen> is the general area in which the emotion occurs.  It indicates a range of possible <fen>Stimulus</fen>.
The <fen>Stimulus</fen> is the person, event, or state of affairs that evokes the emotional response in the <fen>Experiencer</fen>.

The body part, gesture, or other expression of the <fen>Experiencer</fen> that reflects his or her emotional state.  They describe a presentation of the experience or emotion denoted by the adjective or noun.
The <fen>State</fen> is the abstract noun that describes a more lasting experience by the <fen>Experiencer</fen>.
The <fen>Event</fen> is the occasion or happening that <fen>Experiencer</fen>s in a certain emotional state participate in.
The <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Experiencer</fen>, <fen>Expressor</fen>, <fen>Event</fen>, or <fen>State</fen> can be described as having said emotion.
The sentient entity that uses language in the written or spoken modality to convey a <fen>Message</fen> to the <fen>Addressee</fen>.
<fen>Message</fen> is a proposition or set of propositions that the <fen>Communicator</fen> wants the <fen>Addressee</fen> to believe or take for granted.
The <fen>Topic</fen> is the subject matter to which the <fen>Message</fen> pertains. It is normally expressed as a PP Complement headed by 'about', but in some cases it can appear as a direct object.
The physical or abstract setting in which the <fen>Message</fen> is conveyed.
The time at which the communication takes place.
The location where the act of communication occurs.
The phenomenon that signifies the <fen>Indicated</fen>.
The phenomenon that is signified by the <fen>Indicator</fen>.
listRoleExamples: <fex>I</fex> have a tingling sensation in my hands.
The smell <fex>of the garlic</fex> made me hungry.
This herb gives off a smell <fex>of garlic</fex>.
I have a tingling feeling <fex>in my hands</fex>.
<fex>He</fex> finds it hard to communicate with people, not least his separated parents .
How do you communicate to them <fex>that you really like them</fex> ?
Had someone communicated to the capital <fex>about the flagrant disregard of the religious law</fex> ?
Opinions are usually communicated <fex>over the telephone</fex> and are often given within 24 hours.
He was unable to display any <fex>sign</fex> of pain.
We now exhibt the same symptoms <fex>of the same disease</fex>.

sourceCandidateSpans.text: Still Life With a Woman and Four Objects and the Laura-Mulvey
The First White Mother in America
